title.narrative: DR Congo Private Sector Development and Competitiveness Project

description.narrative: The objective of the Private Sector Development and Competitiveness Project for Democratic Republic Congo (DRC) is to support the Borrower's policy of the promotion of private-sector led growth through: (a) improving the investment climate; (b) supporting parastatal reform in the telecommunications, energy, finance, transport, and mining sectors; and (c) improving mining competitiveness in the Katanga region of the Borrower. This restructuring paper seeks your approval to proceed with the extension of the Project closing date by 6 months, from December 31, 2012 to June 30, 2013. The 6 month extension was approved in principle by Regional Vice President (RVP) on October 17, 2012, conditional upon fulfillment of prior actions which have now been satisfied, enabling the transfer of certain activities of high corporate reputation risk to other Bank projects for continuation and completion of their implementation. These include (i) an activity of the Management Action Plan (MAP) approved by the Board in May 2011 in response to an Inspection Panel request on behalf of ex-workers of the mining enterprise Gecamines who took part in a Project-supported labor retrenchment program in 2004-5, and (ii) a critical phase of the National Payments System (NPS) implementation at the Central Bank of Congo (BCC). The extension of closing date would allow the Project to make up for the time lost due to disruptions caused by election related political instability from mid-2011 to January 2012, including a period of one and a half months when the Country Office was closed and all staff evacuated. This is the second extension of the Project, pushing its cumulative extension to 39 months and age to 9 years and 11 months at closing.

condition.narrative: Furnishing to the Association,in form and substance satisfactory to the Association, of the Project Implementation Plan.

title.narrative: All targeted SOEs have some private sector involvement, either through PPP, management contract or other arrangement

target.value: All targeted SOEs have some private sector involvement, either through PPP, management contract or other arrangement

actual.value: Achieved in 5 of 7 strategic SOEs. Other sector projects are supporting.

title.narrative: Return on assets for targeted SOEs (SNEL, SNCC, RVA, OCPT, City Train, Gecamines, LAC) from -21% to 2% by end of project

actual.value: Non-measurable due to lack of data and continuing transformation of balance sheets

title.narrative: Increased net fiscal contribution from parastatals.

actual.value: Achieved. New report for 2012 shows $10.7 million, over 120% higher from 2011, and increasing

title.narrative: Increased FDIs in the mining, transport, energy, telecom and financial sectors.

comment.narrative: Target largely achieved, except when hit by acute external shocks such as in 2009-10

actual.value: Achieved. Over $3.3 billion in 2012 and rising. No 2013 data avail yet

comment.narrative: Target met in 2008, and reinforced by decrees in 2009.

title.narrative: Legal gazette regularly published and available online

target.value: Legal gazette regularly published and available online

title.narrative: ATI: Issuance of Insurance Contracts of $10,000,000 by Y3 and $100,000,000 by Y6.
Number of days to create a company reduced by 50% between 2006 and 2011

comment.narrative: Target largely achieved, with further improvement expected

actual.value: Achieved. New one-stop shop implemented, claims 3 days, but won't have DB assessment till October 2014

comment.narrative: Target largely achieved, while work continues on Single Window (one stop shop) that can process in 3 days

title.narrative: Total domestic credit to private sector increase to 4.8% of GDP by 2011
Total savings (M3) in financial sector increase to 10.4% of GDP by 2011
By end of project, the microfinance sector reaches around 300,000 clients in DRC

actual.value: Achieved. 2012 report shows over 1 million clients

title.narrative: By end 2010, the commercial courts in Kinshasa and Lubumbashi render an average of 50 judgments per year, and the new commercial courts are operational

baseline.value: Commercial courts in Gombe and Matete (Kinshasa) and in Lubumbashi are operational

actual.value: Achieved. 2012 data says 430 judgments, vs 524 in 2011 and 453 in 2010...

comment.narrative: New courts have been added in 5 other cities

title.narrative: Commercial banks compliance with key prudential norms is satisfactory

target.value: All banks respect key prudential ratios

comment.narrative: FSAP will examine in detail in 2013.

title.narrative: By April 2010, the required retrenchment program at SNCC has been completed.

target.value: By April 2010, the required retrenchment program at SNCC has been completed.

comment.narrative: Depends on when the Multimodal Transport Project becomes effective, now scheduled for April 2011

Retrenchment program had to be reformulated as a purely retirement program, with a new requirement for government co-financing ofall salary arrears. Union agreement had to be renegotiated in April 2010. Now awaiting funding from the project, once itsrestructuring/reallocation is completed by April 2011.

title.narrative: By July 2009, inventories of SNCC assets and liabilities are completed.

target.value: By July 2009, inventories of SNCC assets and liabilities are completed

comment.narrative: Complicated by the unfinished liquidation of the predecessor company SNCZ.

title.narrative: By April 2010, an agreement on the settlement of public debts of SNCC has been reached, commercial debts are identified

target.value: By April 2010, an agreement on the settlement of public debts of SNCC has been reached, commercial debts are identified

title.narrative: By July 2010, a restructuring strategy acceptable to IDA for SNCC is approved by the Government (includes the identification and implementation of the most suited divestiture method)

target.value: By July 2010, a restructuring strategy acceptable to IDA for SNCC is approved by the Government (includes the identification andimplementationof the most suited divestiture method)

comment.narrative: Restructuring strategy approved by government in March 2010, to be supported by Multimodal Transport Project approved by Board onJune 29, 2010, in tandem with this project.

title.narrative: OHADA Commission created within 6 months of OHADA ratification and operational within one year

comment.narrative: National OHADA Commission was already inaugurated in April 2010.
